lg.l: In olden days when Rosalind Rosalind. The protagonist of William Shakespeare’s As You Like It (1599), who takes refuge in the Forest of Arden.
Sat ‘neath the beech trees’ shade and dream’d,
While thro’ their downy-satin leaves
The yellow sunshine danc’d and stream’d;
And on the silver boles were hung,
(Soft-flutt'ring in the summer breeze),
The verses by Orlando Orlando. Orlando writes poems to Rosalind that he posts on the trees of the Forest of Arden. sung
Unto the list’ning forest trees;
Then was the reign of old romance
In Arden woods, in lovely France.
In olden days, when Oberon Oberon. The King of the Fairies in William Shakespeare’s A Midsummer Night’s Dream (1595/6), who visits the forest outside Athens.
His revels held on moonlight nights,
And all the woodland ways o’er teem’d
With airy, tiny, glist’ring sprites;
When on the moss Titania Titania. The Queen of the Fairies, who receives a love potion at Oberon’s behest and later imagines her experience has been a dream.
Unseen, slept soft with folded wings,
In an enchanted atmosphere,
Peopled with quaint imaginings;
What fairy tales might have been told
By each great forest monarch A common phrase for a large and ancient tree. old.
Some day, our barren hills Much of the Otago province, in the South Island, was grassland rather than forest at the time of colonisation. may boast
A mantle rich of forest trees,
And oak, and ash, and elm, and beech Oak … ash … elm … beech. English tree species that were introduced by settlers.
May whisper in the summer breeze;
Then will a Rosalind appear,
To fancy’s eye, amid the glades,
And poets dainty lays will sing
Of elves within those woodland shades;
And old-world visions will arise
To bloom anew ‘neath Austral skies.

body.p: —WYCH ELM. Wych Elm. The so-called Scots elm, Ulmus glabra, which was the chosen penname of Marie R. Randle.

Inch Valley, Inch Valley. Marie Randle resided in Inch Valley, in the Otago Province, from 1889-1892, while her husband was head teacher at the local school. August 1892. August 1892. Arbor Day, an annual occasion for planting trees, was first officially observed in New Zealand as a public holiday for government departments and schools on 4 August 1892.
